subject: Real Estate
title: Irrational Exuberance in Housing
description: A 60-second lesson on Irrational Exuberance in Housing.

hook.text: Robert Shiller warned in 2005 that U.S. home prices had detached from fundamentals. Nobody listened.

buildup.text: Prices had doubled in a decade. TV shows taught people to flip houses for quick profit.

discovery.text: Shiller's data showed that real home prices barely grew over the previous century â€” then suddenly surged.

twist.text: Buyers believed a new normal had arrived. Lenders agreed. Both were wrong.

climax.text: The crash proved Shiller right. 'Irrational exuberance' entered the real estate vocabulary permanently.

punchline.text: The smartest warning is always the least popular.

quiz.question: What did Robert Shiller warn about in 2005?
